wikipedia_page.main: Lilian Sheldon (May 1862 – 6 May 1942) was an English zoologist.

link_mentions.page: List of female scientists before the 20th century

response: Alcock taught morphology and anatomy to women students in the Balfour Laboratory for a short period in 1891 and again in 1898–1899, filling in after the resignation of zoologist Lilian Sheldon.

In 1884, she published the first paper by a woman to appear in the Proceedings of the Royal Society. She also published a study on the development of cranial nerves in the newt embryo with Lilian Sheldon, then a student at Newnham College.

Sheldon was born in Handsworth in 1859 where her father was the vicar. or 1860 She had two brothers who survived and four sisters. Her parents Ann (born Sharp) and John Sheldon arranged for their daughters to attend Handsworth Ladies' College and remarkably three of the girls went on to higher education in Cambridge. Lilian Sheldon went to Newnham College and became a noted zoologist
